full_text: Succeed Insurance has specified that the persons involved section of a claim should have a page listing the officials associated with the claim. Information should include the official's name, title, and the number of any filed report. My first step will be to create a page called Claim Officials. In this demo, I shall create the page. I will add it to the UI in a subsequent demo. So, from the Configuration node, I expand Config. Config. Page configuration. Page configuration. Claim. Claim.  I will put the Claim Officials page in the parties involved node, so I right-click the node. And select New. PCF file. The file type of the PCF file will be Page. I will use a suffix of underscore SI for Succeed Insurance, so the full name of the page is Claim Officials underscore SI. I click OK to create the page. The page appears in red, because it has not yet been configured. A list of errors appears below. To begin configuring the page, I click its name. A title is required. I will use a display key, which I have created prior to this demonstration. Next, I create a variable to hold the page. I will hold the claim to which the officials are related. In the Variables tab, I click this button to create a new variable. The variable's name is Claim, with a small c. Its entity type is Claim, with a capital C. The page requires a panel ref to hold data. I click the panel ref icon. And then click in the page to drop a panel ref there. Note that when I add the panel ref, a screen is automatically created to contain it. The panel ref now needs a list view to display the list of officials. There is a list view in the Lost Details node that might serve the purpose. I double-click the editable officials list view to open it. This list view holds the data that is required, so I can use it. I return to the Claim Officials page. I click the panel ref to open its properties. In the definition property of the panel ref I enter the name of the list view, passing it the claim variable. I click the panel ref to open it. Users should be able to edit this list. I select the page. And set its can edit property. And its can visit property both to true. Next, I select the screen. And set its editable property to true. Then, I do the same for the panel ref. From the tool box, I select the edit buttons widget. And drop it into the screen. It is important that the edit buttons go onto the screen, not the page or the panel ref. The edit buttons do not require configuration at this time. Then I select an iterator buttons widget. And drop it onto the panel ref. The iterator buttons require an iterator, so I select them to open their properties. In the iterator property, I type the name of the list view, twice, separated by a period. Finally, I need to provide the page with an entry point, so that the user interface will be able to navigate to it. In the entry points tab, I create a new entry point. The entry point's name must match the name of the page. It needs a parameter to pass the claim to the page from the calling page. To see the layout of the page I have created, I step off it. And then back onto it. The page still has an error, because I haven't added it to a location group yet. I will not be able to see my work in the user interface until I've done so. That is the subject of the next demonstration. This concludes the configuring page components demonstration.

segments.text: Succeed Insurance has specified that the persons involved section of a claim should have a page listing the officials associated with the claim. Information should include the official's name, title, and the number of any filed report. My first step will be to create a page called Claim Officials. In this demo, I shall create the page. I will add it to the UI in a subsequent demo. So, from the Configuration node, I expand Config.
Config.
Page configuration.
Page configuration.
Claim.
Claim.
I will put the Claim Officials page in the parties involved node, so I right-click the node.
And select New.
PCF file.
The file type of the PCF file will be Page.
I will use a suffix of underscore SI for Succeed Insurance, so the full name of the page is Claim Officials underscore SI.
I click OK to create the page.
The page appears in red, because it has not yet been configured.
A list of errors appears below.
To begin configuring the page, I click its name.
A title is required.
I will use a display key, which I have created prior to this demonstration.
Next, I create a variable to hold the page.
I will hold the claim to which the officials are related.
In the Variables tab, I click this button to create a new variable.
The variable's name is Claim, with a small c.
Its entity type is Claim, with a capital C.
The page requires a panel ref to hold data.
I click the panel ref icon.
And then click in the page to drop a panel ref there.
Note that when I add the panel ref, a screen is automatically created to contain it.
The panel ref now needs a list view to display the list of officials.
There is a list view in the Lost Details node that might serve the purpose.
I double-click the editable officials list view to open it.
This list view holds the data that is required, so I can use it.
I return to the Claim Officials page.
I click the panel ref to open its properties.
In the definition property of the panel ref I enter the name of the list view, passing it the claim variable.
I click the panel ref to open it.
Users should be able to edit this list.
I select the page.
And set its can edit property.
And its can visit property both to true.
Next, I select the screen.
And set its editable property to true.
Then, I do the same for the panel ref.
From the tool box, I select the edit buttons widget.
And drop it into the screen.
It is important that the edit buttons go onto the screen, not the page or the panel ref.
The edit buttons do not require configuration at this time.
Then I select an iterator buttons widget.
And drop it onto the panel ref.
The iterator buttons require an iterator, so I select them to open their properties.
In the iterator property, I type the name of the list view, twice, separated by a period.
Finally, I need to provide the page with an entry point, so that the user interface will be able to navigate to it.
In the entry points tab, I create a new entry point.
The entry point's name must match the name of the page.
It needs a parameter to pass the claim to the page from the calling page.
To see the layout of the page I have created, I step off it.
And then back onto it.
The page still has an error, because I haven't added it to a location group yet.
I will not be able to see my work in the user interface until I've done so.
That is the subject of the next demonstration.
This concludes the configuring page components demonstration.
